newsitem.title: USA: Quintiles to acquire Britain's Innovex Ltd.
newsitem.headline: Quintiles to acquire Britain's Innovex Ltd.

text.p: Quintiles Transnational Corp. said Monday it has a definitive agreement to acquire Innovex Ltd., a private British pharmaceutical firm, in a stock deal valued at about $760 million.

Quintiles said the merger would create the world's largest full-service contract pharmaceutical and healthcare company. The combined companies' whose services would include health care product development and information management, research and development, and consulting.
Innovex is believed to be already the world's largest privately held contract pharmaceutical group, supplementing sales and marketing of drugs for 25 pharmaceutical companies, Quintiles said.
Innovex's revenues rose to $129.1 million in the year ended March 31, from $80.4 million in the previous year.
Under the agreement, Quintiles will offer 10 million of its shares for all of Innovex's stock in a pooling of interests. Quintiles has about 20 million outstanding shares.
Its stock rose $2.25 to $76 on Nasdaq at mid-afternoon.
Quintiles, based near Research Triangle Park, N.C., said it expected to take a one-time charge for the acquisition but has not determined the amount.
"The combined company of Quintiles and Innovex, if the deal is completed, would be the largest and fastest-growing services company in this arena," said Quintiles Chairman Dennis Gillings.
"We will provide a unique configuration of services to the pharmaceutical and healthcare sectors, comprising a broader spectrum than any other service company."

The merger is expected to boost earnings by 5 cents to 7 cents per share for 1997, Quintiles spokeswoman Pat Grebe said. In this year's second quarter, Quintiles earned $4.9 million, or 22 cents per share.
The deal is expected to close later this year, pending approval by Quintiles shareholders, the company said.
Quintiles said it would retire about $60 million of existing Innovex debt after the deal closes.
Quintiles, which has 41 operating units in 19 countries, recently announced a definitive merger with BRI International, a contract research organisation based in Arlington, Va.
